Variations.condition:
Probable bacterial meningitis (Adults).
However if Listeria monocytogenes suspected (immunocompromised, elderly, pregnancy, etc) see additional info in Antimicrobial section.
Variations.organisms: Neisseria meningitides Streptococcus pneumoniae
Variations.antimicrobial:
Cefotaxime 2g iv qds PLUS Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd

Consider addition of Dexamethasone phosphate IV 0.15mg/kg qds for 4 days. Ideally steroids should be given either before or at the time of antibiotic administration – if in doubt discuss with Consultant Microbiologist.
Avoid dexamethasone if:
1) Already received antibiotics
2) Septic shock
3) Post neurosurgical meningitis
4) Immunosuppressed patients

Additional Info

Add Amoxicillin 2g iv 4 hrly

Duration (IV therapy only): Meningococcal meningitis: 7 days Pneumococcal meningitis: 10-14 days
Listeria meningitis: 21 days
Variations.alternative:
Penicillin allergy: Meropenem 2g iv tds
PLUS Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd
Variations.comments:
Investigations: Blood cultures, CSF, EDTA bottle (meningococcal & pneumococcal PCR), throat swab

Commence IV antibiotics as soon as possible. Do not wait for CSF sampling if delay expected.

Steroid therapy has been shown to be most beneficial in adults with pneumococcal meningitis.

Refer to Connolly Hospital Infection Prevention and Control manual re infection prevention and control precautions and patient placement.

Inform Public Health doctors

Seek advice from Consultant Microbiologist in all cases

Variations.antimicrobial:
Mild (not systemically unwell) Flucloxacillin 500mg po qds Duration: 7 days

Moderate (signs of systemic toxicity or progressive cellulitis) Flucloxacillin 2g iv qds Duration: 10-14 days

Severe (rapidly progressive cellulitis with severe sepsis/shock) Discuss with Consultant Microbiologist as possibility of deeper infection such as necrotising fasciitis should be considered Duration: 10-14 days
Variations.alternative:
Mild Penicillin allergy (non-anaphylaxis): Cephalexin 500mg po tds

MRSA positive (or penicillin anaphylaxis): Doxycycline 100mg po bd or Clindamycin 450 mg po qds (if susceptible - check with microbiology laboratory)

ModerateMRSA positive or penicillin allergy: Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd
Variations.comments:
Investigations: Blood cultures (if systemic features), swab if exudates present, check CRP/ESR/WBC, demarcate on patients skin outer border of cellulitis, check MRSA status if in-patient or recent healthcare contact

Note flucloxacillin has activity against both meticillin sensitive S. aureus and ß- Haemolytic streptococci so addition of benzylpenicillin is not indicated Clindamycin associated with increased risk of Clostridium difficile associated diarrhoea – reserve its use to defined indications as set out in these guidelines

Variations.alternative: Contact Consultant Microbiologist
Variations.comments:
Sodium fusidate interacts with statins and there is a significant risk of myopathy/rhabdomyolysis. Concurrent use will require either temporary discontinuation of statin or close medical supervision. Consult pharmacy for advice.

Deep bone specimens/Joint aspiration (prior to treatment if possible) are essential to establish diagnosis and further management. Do not rely on the results of superficial swabs of ulcers to identify the cause(s) of the bone infection Consider gonococcal septic arthritis in young adult (send STD screen and contact Consultant Microbiologist)
Further therapy should be discussed with Consultant Microbiologist
